Class AbstractKeyCollection

  • java.lang.Object
    • AbstractKeyCollection
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    KeyCollectionDecomposed, KeyCollectionMonolithic

    public abstract class AbstractKeyCollection
extends java.lang.Object
    This abstract class for the graded homework assignment in Series 1 of 2IPC0 provides an auxiliary function and the signature of isSecure().

    A particular type of key to open a lock consists of two rows of indentations of varying depth. The indentation depth varies from 1 to 5. The rows are not necessarily of equal length. You can convert one key into another key by deepening some of the indentations of the first key. Of course, the resulting key has the same row lengths for corresponding rows.

    For example, if the depths of the first key are {{1, 2}, {5, 1, 1}}, then it can be converted into the key {{2, 2}, {5, 1, 3}}, but not into the keys {{2, 1}, {5, 1, 3}} and {{1, 3, 1}, {5, 2, 1}}.

    A collection of keys is called secure, when no key in the set can be converted into another key in the set.

    In the following code, the number of rows and the maximum indentation depth is parameterized by the constants N_ROWS and MAX_DEPTH.

    Since:
    14 Nov 2012

    • Method Detail

      • isKey

        public boolean isKey(int[][] key)
        Determines whether the given integer array represents a key.
        Parameters:
        key - the key to be checked
        Returns:
        whether key represents a key.
        Precondition:
        true
        Modifies:
        None
        Postcondition:
        \result == (key != null && key.length == N_ROWS && B
        where
        • B = (\forall r; key.has(r); key[r] != null && key[r].length != 0 && (\forall i; key[r].has(i); 1 <= key[r][i] <= MAX_DEPTH))

      • isSecure

        public abstract boolean isSecure(int[][][] keys)
        Determines whether the given set of keys is secure. Not robust.
        Parameters:
        keys - array with the keys
        Returns:
        whether keys forms a secure set of keys
        Precondition:
        keys != null && (\forall k; keys.has(k); isKey(keys[k])
        Modifies:
        None
        Postcondition:
        \result == (\forall k1, k2; keys.has(k1) && keys.has(k2) && k1 != k2; ! CK(keys[k1], keys[k2])),
        where
        • CK(key1, key2) = (\forall r; key1.has(r); CR(key1[r], key2[r])),
        • CR(row1, row2) = row1.length == row2.length && (\forall i; row1.has(i); row1[i] <= row2[i])
